Other possible factors in the pathway between Zika infection and microcephaly have been suggested, the most important of which is the socioeconomic deprivation in the Brazilian NE
16, 51 . This is a typical confounding problem, not easily addressed, mainly due to the larger reservoirs of Aedes aegypti in poor areas and increased awareness of the microcephaly risk in the upper socioeconomic classes, inducing either postponing pregnancy during epidemic periods or voluntary abortion, not legal in Brazil
52 .
